message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's age suggests that she should have met certain developmental milestones. At 2 months, infants should exhibit social smiles in response to faces (option C). Absence of asymmetric tonic neck reflex and monosyllabic babble typically occur around 6 months of age, while staring at their own hands usually occurs around 3 months of age.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's age indicates that they should have met several developmental milestones. Absence of asymmetric tonic neck reflex is expected at 4 months, monosyllabic babble is expected at 4-6 months, and staring at their own hand is expected at 5-6 months. However, a 2-month-old infant smiling in response to a face is a normal developmental milestone.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A 2-month-old infant who is exclusively breastfed will typically have a pulse rate of 100 to 160/min and a respiratory rate of 30 to 60/min. The blood pressure is within the normal range for infants. At this age, infants should be able to smile in response to a face, which is the developmental milestone that this patient most likely met. Asymmetric tonic neck reflex and monosyllabic babble occur at earlier ages, while staring at own hand is not a specific developmental milestone.
We refer to developmental milestones charts for help. At 2 months of age, the patient is expected to smile in response to a face. Options A, B, and D are expected at later stages of development.

The absence of the asymmetric tonic neck reflex is a milestone at 4-6 months, monosyllabic babble at 6 months, and staring at own hand at 3-4 months.

Absence of the asymmetric tonic neck reflex is expected at 6 months of age, monosyllabic babble is expected at 4-6 months of age, and staring at their own hand is expected at around 1-2 months of age.

The absence of asymmetric tonic neck reflex is a milestone at around 6 months, monosyllabic babble at around 4-6 months, and staring at own hands at around 2-3 months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's age and physical examination findings suggest that she has met the developmental milestone of smiling in response to a face. The absence of asymmetric tonic neck reflex is a developmental milestone for 4-6 months of age. Monosyllabic babble and staring at own hand are developmental milestones for 3-4 months of age.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is 2 months old and weighs 5,200 g (11 lb 8 oz), which falls within the normal range for this age. The normal pulse rate for a 2-month-old is 100-160/min, and the normal respiratory rate is 30-60/min. The normal systolic blood pressure for a 2-month-old is 80-100 mm Hg, and the normal diastolic blood pressure is 50-70 mm Hg. Among the options, smiling in response to a face is a developmental milestone typically achieved at around 2 months of age. Asymmetric tonic neck reflex is typically present until around 6 months of age, monosyllabic babble begins around 4-6 months of age, and staring at one's own hand is typically seen around 2-3 months of age.

We refer to guidelines on developmental milestones in infants for help. At 2 months old, babies should be able to smile in response to faces. The other options are milestones seen at earlier ages (absence of asymmetric tonic neck reflex and staring at own hand) or later ages (monosyllabic babble).
